overview: Married Couple’s Allowance (MCA) reduces your tax bill - what you'll get, eligibility and applying
title: Married Couple's Allowance

parts.body:
Married Couple's Allowance could reduce your tax bill by £280 to £729.50 a year.

You must be married or in a civil partnership to claim and one of you must have been **born before 6 April 1935**.

For marriages before 5 December 2005 the husband's income is used to work out Married Couple's Allowance. For marriage and civil partnerships after this date, it's the income of the highest earner.
parts.title: Overview

parts.body:
Married Couple's Allowance could reduce your tax bill by £280 to £729.50 a year.

You get this allowance for each tax year (or part of the year) that you're married or in a civil partnership.

$E
**Example:** If you marry on 24 March you'll get a 12th (one month's worth) of the allowance for that tax year, which begins 6 April.
$E

If one of you dies, or if you divorce or separate, your allowance continues until the end of that tax year.

$!Use the [Married Couple's Allowance calculator](/calculate-married-couples-allowance "Married Couple's Allowance calculator") to work out if you qualify and how much you could get.$!
parts.title: What you'll get

parts.body:
You can claim Married Couple's Allowance if:

- you're married or in a civil partnership 
- you're a taxpayer
- one of you was **born before 6 April 1935**

$!Use the [Married Couple's Allowance calculator](/calculate-married-couples-allowance "Married Couple's Allowance calculator") to work out if you qualify and how much you could get.$!
parts.title: Eligibility

parts.body:
Contact HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC) to claim.

You must give details of your:

- marriage or civil partnership ceremony
- spouse or civil partner - including date of birth

parts.title: How to claim

parts.body:
##Transfer your MCA after the end of the tax year
If your spouse or civil partner pays tax, you can transfer any unused allowance to them if:

- you don’t pay tax
- your tax bill isn't high enough

Use the form below or contact [HM Revenue & Customs (HMRC)](/married-couples-allowance#how-to-claim "Contact HM Revenue & Customs") who can post you a copy. 

$D
[Download form 575 'Notice of transfer of surplus Income Tax allowances' - (PDF, 64KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/575-t-man.pdf "Form 575 - Notice of transfer of surplus Income Tax allowances"){:rel="external"} 
$D

##Share or transfer your MCA before the start of the tax year
You and your spouse (or civil partner) can also:

- share the minimum MCA
- transfer the whole of the minimum MCA from one to the other

Complete the form below before the start of the tax year - you can also contact [HMRC](/married-couples-allowance#how-to-claim "Contact HM Revenue & Customs") to get a copy in the post.

$D
[Download form 18 'Transferring the Married Couple’s Allowance' - (PDF, 88KB)](http://www.hmrc.gov.uk/forms/18.pdf "form 18 - Transferring the Married Couple’s Allowance"){:rel="external"}
$D

##Tax allowances and giving to charity

If you pay tax and give money to a UK charity using Gift Aid, let [HMRC](/married-couples-allowance#how-to-claim "HM Revenue & Customs") know. It reduces your income when they calculate your age-related allowances.



*[MCA]: Married Couple's Allowance
*[HMRC]: HM Revenue & Customs
